comment_text.mn64:2.5: As at SN 45.179, AN 10.13, etc. They are “lower fetters” because they bind sentient beings to rebirth in lower planes.
comment_text.mn64:3.1: Given that Māluṅkyaputta got the answer right, it is not clear why the Buddha adopted the reproving tone that he would normally use in response to a dangerously mistaken view (MN 22:6.1). The commentary explains that he had the view that fetters were only present when active, hence the Buddha’s simile to follow. Regardless, as compared to MN 63, Māluṅkyaputta is making progress, as he gives a serious answer to an important question and appears to no longer be on the verge of disrobing.
comment_text.mn64:3.13: For other accounts of infant development in relation to defilements, see AN 10.99:6.2 and MN 38:26.1.
comment_text.mn64:9.2: The opening clause is a unique addition to the standard jhāna formula. | In later texts, “seclusion from attachments” (upadhiviveka) signified arahantship (Mnd 14:10.1), but here it must have a less exalted sense. Perhaps it refers to leaving behind the material things to which one is attached (SN 1.2). | For “bodily discomfort”, see MN 127:16.7.
comment_text.mn64:9.3: This shows the development of insight based directly on the absorption.
comment_text.mn64:15.5: The final formless attainment is omitted as at MN 52:14.7.
comment_text.mn64:16.1: “Released in heart“ and “released by wisdom” indicate an emphasis on either immersion or wisdom respectively.
comment_text.mn64:16.2: The Buddha makes the same point at SN 48.13 and SN 48:16. For more on the “disparity of faculties”, see MN 66:14.6.

root_text.mn64:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn64:2.1: “dhāretha no tumhe, bhikkhave, mayā desitāni pañcorambhāgiyāni saṁyojanānī”ti?
root_text.mn64:2.2: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn64:2.3: “ahaṁ kho, bhante, dhāremi bhagavatā desitāni pañcorambhāgiyāni saṁyojanānī”ti.
root_text.mn64:2.4: “Yathā kathaṁ pana tvaṁ, mālukyaputta, dhāresi mayā desitāni pañcorambhāgiyāni saṁyojanānī”ti?
root_text.mn64:2.5: “Sakkāyadiṭṭhiṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā orambhāgiyaṁ saṁyojanaṁ desitaṁ dhāremi;
root_text.mn64:2.6: vicikicchaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā orambhāgiyaṁ saṁyojanaṁ desitaṁ dhāremi;
root_text.mn64:2.7: sīlabbataparāmāsaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā orambhāgiyaṁ saṁyojanaṁ desitaṁ dhāremi;
root_text.mn64:2.8: kāmacchandaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā orambhāgiyaṁ saṁyojanaṁ desitaṁ dhāremi;
root_text.mn64:2.9: byāpādaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā orambhāgiyaṁ saṁyojanaṁ desitaṁ dhāremi.
root_text.mn64:2.10: Evaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, dhāremi bhagavatā desitāni pañcorambhāgiyāni saṁyojanānī”ti.
root_text.mn64:3.1: “Kassa kho nāma tvaṁ, mālukyaputta, imāni evaṁ pañcorambhāgiyāni saṁyojanāni desitāni dhāresi?
root_text.mn64:3.2: Nanu, mālukyaputta, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā iminā taruṇūpamena upārambhena upārambhissanti?
root_text.mn64:3.3: Daharassa hi, mālukyaputta, kumārassa mandassa uttānaseyyakassa sakkāyotipi na hoti, kuto panassa uppajjissati sakkāyadiṭṭhi?
root_text.mn64:3.5: Daharassa hi, mālukyaputta, kumārassa mandassa uttānaseyyakassa dhammātipi na hoti, kuto panassa uppajjissati dhammesu vicikicchā?
root_text.mn64:3.7: Daharassa hi, mālukyaputta, kumārassa mandassa uttānaseyyakassa sīlātipi na hoti, kuto panassa uppajjissati sīlesu sīlabbataparāmāso?
root_text.mn64:3.9: Daharassa hi, mālukyaputta, kumārassa mandassa uttānaseyyakassa kāmātipi na hoti, kuto panassa uppajjissati kāmesu kāmacchando?
root_text.mn64:3.11: Daharassa hi, mālukyaputta, kumārassa mandassa uttānaseyyakassa sattātipi na hoti, kuto panassa uppajjissati sattesu byāpādo?
root_text.mn64:3.13: Nanu, mālukyaputta, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā iminā taruṇūpamena upārambhena upārambhissantī”ti?
root_text.mn64:4.1: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn64:4.3: yaṁ bhagavā pañcorambhāgiyāni saṁyojanāni deseyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
root_text.mn64:4.4: “Tena hānanda, suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn64:4.5: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.
root_text.mn64:5.1: “Idhānanda, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṁ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṁ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
root_text.mn64:5.3: uppannāya ca sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
root_text.mn64:5.4: Tassa sā sakkāyadiṭṭhi thāmagatā appaṭivinītā orambhāgiyaṁ saṁyojanaṁ.
root_text.mn64:5.6: uppannāya ca vicikicchāya nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
root_text.mn64:5.7: Tassa sā vicikicchā thāmagatā appaṭivinītā orambhāgiyaṁ saṁyojanaṁ.
root_text.mn64:5.9: uppannassa ca sīlabbataparāmāsassa nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
root_text.mn64:5.10: Tassa so sīlabbataparāmāso thāmagato appaṭivinīto orambhāgiyaṁ saṁyojanaṁ.
root_text.mn64:5.12: uppannassa ca kāmarāgassa nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
root_text.mn64:5.13: Tassa so kāmarāgo thāmagato appaṭivinīto orambhāgiyaṁ saṁyojanaṁ.
root_text.mn64:5.15: uppannassa ca byāpādassa nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
root_text.mn64:5.16: Tassa so byāpādo thāmagato appaṭivinīto orambhāgiyaṁ saṁyojanaṁ.
root_text.mn64:6.1: Sutavā ca kho, ānanda, ariyasāvako ariyānaṁ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto, sappurisānaṁ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto na sakkāyadiṭṭhipariyuṭṭhitena cetasā viharati na sakkāyadiṭṭhiparetena;
root_text.mn64:6.2: uppannāya ca sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn64:6.4: Na vicikicchāpariyuṭṭhitena cetasā viharati na vicikicchāparetena;
root_text.mn64:6.5: uppannāya ca vicikicchāya nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn64:6.7: Na sīlabbataparāmāsapariyuṭṭhitena cetasā viharati na sīlabbataparāmāsaparetena;
root_text.mn64:6.8: uppannassa ca sīlabbataparāmāsassa nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn64:6.10: Na kāmarāgapariyuṭṭhitena cetasā viharati na kāmarāgaparetena;
root_text.mn64:6.11: uppannassa ca kāmarāgassa nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn64:6.13: Na byāpādapariyuṭṭhitena cetasā viharati na byāpādaparetena;
root_text.mn64:6.14: uppannassa ca byāpādassa nissaraṇaṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn64:6.16: Yo, ānanda, maggo yā paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāya taṁ maggaṁ taṁ paṭipadaṁ anāgamma pañcorambhāgiyāni saṁyojanāni ñassati vā dakkhati vā pajahissati vāti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn64:6.17: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato tacaṁ acchetvā phegguṁ acchetvā sāracchedo bhavissatīti—
root_text.mn64:6.19: evameva kho, ānanda, yo maggo yā paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāya taṁ maggaṁ taṁ paṭipadaṁ anāgamma pañcorambhāgiyāni saṁyojanāni ñassati vā dakkhati vā pajahissati vāti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn64:7.1: Yo ca kho, ānanda, maggo yā paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāya taṁ maggaṁ taṁ paṭipadaṁ āgamma pañcorambhāgiyāni saṁyojanāni ñassati vā dakkhati vā pajahissati vāti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn64:8.1: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato tacaṁ chetvā phegguṁ chetvā sāracchedo bhavissatīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn64:8.2: evameva kho, ānanda, yo maggo yā paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāya taṁ maggaṁ taṁ paṭipadaṁ āgamma pañcorambhāgiyāni saṁyojanāni ñassati vā dakkhati vā pajahissati vāti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn64:8.3: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, gaṅgā nadī pūrā udakassa samatittikā kākapeyyā.
root_text.mn64:8.5: ‘ahaṁ imissā gaṅgāya nadiyā tiriyaṁ bāhāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ gacchissāmī’ti;
root_text.mn64:8.6: so na sakkuṇeyya gaṅgāya nadiyā tiriyaṁ bāhāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ gantuṁ.
root_text.mn64:8.7: Evameva kho, ānanda, yesaṁ kesañci sakkāyanirodhāya dhamme desiyamāne cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati;
root_text.mn64:8.8: seyyathāpi so dubbalako puriso evamete daṭṭhabbā.
root_text.mn64:8.9: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, gaṅgā nadī pūrā udakassa samatittikā kākapeyyā.
root_text.mn64:8.11: ‘ahaṁ imissā gaṅgāya nadiyā tiriyaṁ bāhāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ gacchissāmī’ti;
root_text.mn64:8.12: so sakkuṇeyya gaṅgāya nadiyā tiriyaṁ bāhāya sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ gantuṁ.
root_text.mn64:8.13: Evameva kho, ānanda, yesaṁ kesañci sakkāyanirodhāya dhamme desiyamāne cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati;
root_text.mn64:8.14: seyyathāpi so balavā puriso evamete daṭṭhabbā.
root_text.mn64:9.1: Katamo cānanda, maggo, katamā paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāya?
root_text.mn64:9.2: Idhānanda, bhikkhu upadhivivekā akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānā sabbaso kāyaduṭṭhullānaṁ paṭippassaddhiyā vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn64:9.3: So yadeva tattha hoti rūpagataṁ vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ te dhamme aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassati.
root_text.mn64:9.5: So tehi dhammehi cittaṁ paṭivāpetvā amatāya dhātuyā cittaṁ upasaṁharati:
root_text.mn64:9.6: ‘etaṁ santaṁ etaṁ paṇītaṁ yadidaṁ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
root_text.mn64:9.7: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti;
root_text.mn64:9.8: no ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti, tattha parinibbāyī, anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
root_text.mn64:9.9: Ayampi kho, ānanda, maggo ayaṁ paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāya.
root_text.mn64:10-12.1: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
root_text.mn64:10-12.4: So yadeva tattha hoti rūpagataṁ vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ …
root_text.mn64:10-12.7: Ayampi kho, ānanda, maggo ayaṁ paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāya.
root_text.mn64:13.1: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn64:13.2: So yadeva tattha hoti vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ …
root_text.mn64:13.5: Ayampi kho, ānanda, maggo ayaṁ paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāya.
root_text.mn64:14.1: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn64:14.2: So yadeva tattha hoti vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ …
root_text.mn64:14.5: Ayampi kho, ānanda, maggo ayaṁ paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāya.
root_text.mn64:15.1: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn64:15.2: So yadeva tattha hoti vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ …
root_text.mn64:15.5: Ayampi kho, ānanda, maggo ayaṁ paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāyā”ti.
root_text.mn64:16.1: “Eso ce, bhante, maggo esā paṭipadā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānāya, atha kiñcarahi idhekacce bhikkhū cetovimuttino ekacce bhikkhū paññāvimuttino”ti?
root_text.mn64:16.4: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn64:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn64:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn64:2.1: “Mendicants, do you remember the five lower fetters taught by me?”
translation_text.mn64:2.2: When he said this, Venerable Māluṅkyaputta said to him,
translation_text.mn64:2.5: “I remember the lower fetters taught by the Buddha as follows: substantialist view,
translation_text.mn64:2.10: That’s how I remember the five lower fetters taught by the Buddha.”
translation_text.mn64:3.1: “Who on earth do you remember being taught the five lower fetters in that way?
translation_text.mn64:3.2: Wouldn’t the wanderers of other religions fault you using the simile of the infant?
translation_text.mn64:3.3: For a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘substantial reality’, so how could substantialist view possibly arise in them?
translation_text.mn64:3.4: Yet the underlying tendency to substantialist view still lies within them.
translation_text.mn64:3.5: A little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘teachings’, so how could doubt about the teachings possibly arise in them?
translation_text.mn64:3.6: Yet the underlying tendency to doubt still lies within them.
translation_text.mn64:3.7: A little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘precepts’, so how could misapprehension of precepts and observances possibly arise in them?
translation_text.mn64:3.8: Yet the underlying tendency to misapprehension of precepts and observances still lies within them.
translation_text.mn64:3.9: A little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘sensual pleasures’, so how could desire for sensual pleasures possibly arise in them?
translation_text.mn64:3.10: Yet the underlying tendency to sensual desire still lies within them.
translation_text.mn64:3.11: A little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘sentient beings’, so how could ill will for sentient beings possibly arise in them?
translation_text.mn64:3.12: Yet the underlying tendency to ill will still lies within them.
translation_text.mn64:3.13: Wouldn’t the wanderers of other religions fault you using the simile of the infant?”
translation_text.mn64:4.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn64:4.2: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
translation_text.mn64:4.3: May the Buddha teach the five lower fetters. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
translation_text.mn64:4.4: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn64:5.1: “Ānanda, take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.
translation_text.mn64:5.2: Their heart is overcome and mired in substantialist view,
translation_text.mn64:5.3: and they don’t truly understand the escape from substantialist view that has arisen.
translation_text.mn64:5.4: That substantialist view is entrenched in them, not eliminated: it is a lower fetter.
translation_text.mn64:5.5: Their heart is overcome and mired in doubt,
translation_text.mn64:5.6: and they don’t truly understand the escape from doubt that has arisen.
translation_text.mn64:5.7: That doubt is entrenched in them, not eliminated: it is a lower fetter.
translation_text.mn64:5.8: Their heart is overcome and mired in misapprehension of precepts and observances,
translation_text.mn64:5.9: and they don’t truly understand the escape from misapprehension of precepts and observances that has arisen.
translation_text.mn64:5.10: That misapprehension of precepts and observances is entrenched in them, not eliminated: it is a lower fetter.
translation_text.mn64:5.11: Their heart is overcome and mired in sensual desire,
translation_text.mn64:5.12: and they don’t truly understand the escape from sensual desire that has arisen.
translation_text.mn64:5.13: That sensual desire is entrenched in them, not eliminated: it is a lower fetter.
translation_text.mn64:5.14: Their heart is overcome and mired in ill will,
translation_text.mn64:5.15: and they don’t truly understand the escape from ill will that has arisen.
translation_text.mn64:5.16: That ill will is entrenched in them, not eliminated: it is a lower fetter.
translation_text.mn64:6.1: But a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons. Their heart is not overcome and mired in substantialist view,
translation_text.mn64:6.2: and they truly understand the escape from substantialist view that has arisen.
translation_text.mn64:6.3: That substantialist view, along with any underlying tendency to it, is given up in them.
translation_text.mn64:6.4: Their heart is not overcome and mired in doubt,
translation_text.mn64:6.5: and they truly understand the escape from doubt that has arisen.
translation_text.mn64:6.6: That doubt, along with any underlying tendency to it, is given up in them.
translation_text.mn64:6.7: Their heart is not overcome and mired in misapprehension of precepts and observances,
translation_text.mn64:6.8: and they truly understand the escape from misapprehension of precepts and observances that has arisen.
translation_text.mn64:6.9: That misapprehension of precepts and observances, along with any underlying tendency to it, is given up in them.
translation_text.mn64:6.10: Their heart is not overcome and mired in sensual desire,
translation_text.mn64:6.11: and they truly understand the escape from sensual desire that has arisen.
translation_text.mn64:6.12: That sensual desire, along with any underlying tendency to it, is given up in them.
translation_text.mn64:6.13: Their heart is not overcome and mired in ill will,
translation_text.mn64:6.14: and they truly understand the escape from ill will that has arisen.
translation_text.mn64:6.15: That ill will, along with any underlying tendency to it, is given up in them.
translation_text.mn64:6.16: There is a path and a practice for giving up the five lower fetters. It’s not possible to know or see or give up the five lower fetters without relying on that path and that practice.
translation_text.mn64:6.17: Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood. It’s not possible to cut out the heartwood without having cut through the bark and the softwood.
translation_text.mn64:6.19: In the same way, there is a path and a practice for giving up the five lower fetters. It’s not possible to know or see or give up the five lower fetters without relying on that path and that practice.
translation_text.mn64:7.1: But it is possible to know and see and give up the five lower fetters by relying on that path and that practice.
translation_text.mn64:8.1: Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood. It is possible to cut out the heartwood after having cut through the bark and the softwood.
translation_text.mn64:8.2: In the same way, there is a path and a practice for giving up the five lower fetters. It is possible to know and see and give up the five lower fetters by relying on that path and that practice.
translation_text.mn64:8.3: Suppose the river Ganges was full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
translation_text.mn64:8.4: Then along comes a feeble person, who thinks:
translation_text.mn64:8.5: ‘By swimming with my arms I’ll safely cross over to the far shore of the Ganges.’
translation_text.mn64:8.6: But they’re not able to do so.
translation_text.mn64:8.7: In the same way, when the Dhamma is being taught for the cessation of substantial reality, someone whose mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided
translation_text.mn64:8.8: should be regarded as being like that feeble person.
translation_text.mn64:8.9: Suppose the river Ganges was full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
translation_text.mn64:8.10: Then along comes a strong person, who thinks:
translation_text.mn64:8.11: ‘By swimming with my arms I’ll safely cross over to the far shore of the Ganges.’
translation_text.mn64:8.12: And they are able to do so.
translation_text.mn64:8.13: In the same way, when the Dhamma is being taught for the cessation of substantial reality, someone whose mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided
translation_text.mn64:8.14: should be regarded as being like that strong person.
translation_text.mn64:9.1: And what, Ānanda, is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters?
translation_text.mn64:9.2: It’s when a mendicant—due to the seclusion from attachments, the giving up of unskillful qualities, and the complete settling of physical discomforts—quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn64:9.3: They contemplate the phenomena there—included in form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as gloom, as an affliction, as alien, as breaking apart, as empty, as not-self.
translation_text.mn64:9.4: They turn their mind away from those things,
translation_text.mn64:9.5: and apply it to the element free of death:
translation_text.mn64:9.6: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’
translation_text.mn64:9.7: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn64:9.8: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.mn64:9.9: This is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters.
translation_text.mn64:10-12.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption …
translation_text.mn64:10-12.4: They contemplate the phenomena there—included in form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent …
translation_text.mn64:10-12.5: They turn their mind away from those things …
translation_text.mn64:10-12.6: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, they’re reborn spontaneously … and are not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.mn64:10-12.7: This too is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters.
translation_text.mn64:13.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.mn64:13.2: They contemplate the phenomena there—included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent …
translation_text.mn64:13.3: They turn their mind away from those things …
translation_text.mn64:13.4: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, they’re reborn spontaneously … and are not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.mn64:13.5: This too is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters.
translation_text.mn64:14.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.mn64:14.2: They contemplate the phenomena there—included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent …
translation_text.mn64:14.3: They turn their mind away from those things …
translation_text.mn64:14.4: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, they’re reborn spontaneously … and are not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.mn64:14.5: This too is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters.
translation_text.mn64:15.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.mn64:15.2: They contemplate the phenomena there—included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent …
translation_text.mn64:15.3: They turn their mind away from those things …
translation_text.mn64:15.4: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, they’re reborn spontaneously … and are not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.mn64:15.5: This too is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters.”
translation_text.mn64:16.1: “Sir, if this is the path and the practice for giving up the five lower fetters, how then are some mendicants here released in heart while others are released by wisdom?”
translation_text.mn64:16.2: “In that case, I say it is the disparity of their faculties.”
translation_text.mn64:16.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn64:16.4: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.mn64:16.2: Ettha kho panesāhaṁ → ettha kho tesāhaṁ (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)
